subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit And Larger Scale Tests

X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=331284687; y=zPf-v-IznTrxim5g8BL_AOuU3_MtXu3Yj5LUCWYVXrmJLpEaMRB-Peg
X-Yahoo-Profile: daniel.brolund

Hi,

On Wed, 2008-09-17 at 22:44 +0100, Nat Pryce wrote:
> 2008/9/17 Jan Kroeze <thejcwk@...>:
> > Hi!
> >
> > I think I understand your point #1, but I'm not quite sure. Why was
> it
> > difficult to locate the specific tests?
> 
> FIT lets you mix tests and freeform text, write documents that link to
> tests, index tests in different ways, etc. etc. That's harder to do
> with JUnit. We could have linked from our wiki to JUnit tests in
> Subversion, which would have helped but made refactoring more
> difficult.
> 

As a complement to FIT you can use Bumblebee, which turns the
documentation structure the other way around in that it creates
documents from the JUnit test structure, and allows you to write
comments in the classes and methods of the tests and suites, an kind of
AgileDox++.
It also allows you to save runtime data to put in the resulting
document, so you could report e.g. partly failures.

Bumblebee does not give you the same ease of working together with the
customer around the document as FIT. On the other hand it integrates the
code and the documentation more tightly, making it easier to refactor
code and documentation together.

Bumblebee is a free, open source extension for JUnit(4.4+), available
at 
http://agical.com/bumblebee/download/
with documentation (and an example of what it might look like) at
http://agical.com/bumblebee/bumblebee_doc.html

Cheers
Daniel


> > Your second point has been mentioned by quite a few people on the
> list.
> > Would I be correct if I thought of this factor as a major factor in
> making
> > the decision to migrate to FIT or something similar?
> 
> It's one of many factors. Refactoring and tool support are also
> factors to take into account.
> 
> >
> > 2008/9/14 Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...>
> >
> >> I've used JUnit for system testing as well as unit testing.
> >>
> >> It worked pretty well -- JUnit has great tool support, is small and
> >> simple and, being plain old Java, is easy to extend or plug onto
> >> existing APIs and external systems.
> >>
> >> The two main drawbacks we found were:
> >>
> >> 1) Too hard to go back and find out about the system behaviour from
> >> the tests. We refactored our tests agressively into a "domain
> >> specific embedded language" for describing business rules, but it
> was
> >> difficult to find the test(s) we needed to read to understand why
> the
> >> system did what it did.
> >>
> >
> >>
> >> 2) A JUnit test aborts completely on failure. For system tests, we
> >> wanted to distinguish between fatal failures that should abort the
> >> test, and failures that allowed the test to continue running. For
> >> example, a system that displays calculations in a table should fail
> >> the test if any calculations are incorrect and report *all* the
> >> incorrect calculations, not abort as soon as it detects a single
> >> incorrect calculation.
> >>
> >> FIT and similar tools address these issues much better than JUnit,
> but
> >> you sacrifice easy refactoring.
> >>
> >> --Nat
> >>
> >> 2008/9/8 Jan Kroeze <thejcwk@... <thejcwk%40gmail.com>>:
> >>
> >> > Hi!
> >> >
> >> > Very good point about acceptance testing and system boundaries. I
> hadn't
> >> > thought of this and people often forget to mention it. Of course,
> this
> >> has a
> >> > great effect on the tools you end up using.
> >> >
> >> > Also, I agree regarding the combinatorial explosion problem. I
> had to
> >> write
> >> > a Lexer for a toy programming language in one of my courses and
> having a
> >> > unit test for each input pattern helped to narrow down problems
> so
> >> quickly
> >> > that I finished in ~3 hours!
> >> >
> >> > People here at varsity also seldom miss the point about testing
> scope.
> >> They
> >> > seem to assume that every level of testing will always be used,
> and
> >> > teach
> >> > accordingly. I think it's important to note that this is not
> always
> >> > neccessary.
> >> >
> >> > Thanks for the distinction you made between integration tests and
> larger
> >> > scale ones. I think I understand a little better where the
> boundaries
> >> > lie
> >> :)
> >> >
> >> > 2008/9/4 lancezant <lancezant@... <lancezant%
> 40hotmail.com>>
> >> >
> >> >> Hi Jan,
> >> >>
> >> >> I agree, and as you touch on the idea of acceptance tests, you
> come
> >> >> close to the one point I'd add. Besides running time and number
> of
> >> >> failures, the other distinguishing feature of acceptance tests
> is that
> >> >> the interacts often cross the system's boundary. By that I mean
> input
> >> >> comes through non-java interfaces such as GUIs, message systems,
> etc.
> >> >> and output involve more side effects (i.e. go to places other
> than
> >> >> back to the source). In some cases, these can be shoehorned into
> a
> >> >> Java interface (e.g. httpunit) but this is often where the need
> for
> >> >> other tools comes in.
> >> >>
> >> >> The reason for fine-grained testing is that large-grained tests
> are
> >> >> overwhelmed by combinatoric explosion of conditions long before
> they
> >> >> achieve reasonable coverage. The "unit" is usually a single
> class.
> >> >> The system can be tens to thousands of classes. For small
> systems,
> >> >> the gap may be small enough that unit and acceptance tests are
> >> >> sufficient.
> >> >>
> >> >> Often, however, it is useful to have integration tests in
> between. By
> >> >> testing clusters of collaborating classes, integration tests can
> >> >> further reduce the number of acceptance tests needed to achieve
> >> >> reasonable coverage. The thing integration tests have in common
> with
> >> >> unit tests is that by being entirely within the system boundary,
> they
> >> >> can reuse much of the Java infrastructure, including JUnit, mock
> >> >> objects, etc.
> >> >>
> >> >> Best regards,
> >> >> Lance
> >> >>
> >> >>
> >> >> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com> <junit%
> >> 40yahoogroups.com>, "Jan Kroeze"
> >>
> >> >> <thejcwk@...> wrote:
> >> >> >
> >> >> > Hi!
> >> >> >
> >> >> > I think this summarises quite neatly what a couple of people
> have
> >> >> said,
> >> >> > namely that switching to a dedicated framework from JUnit is
> only
> >> >> neccessary
> >> >> > if there are quite a few / complicated integration tests.
> >> >> >
> >> >> > I happen to agree with this, since introducing more and more
> >> >> frameworks into
> >> >> > your project just for testing will certainly drive many
> programmers
> >> >> up the
> >> >> > walls. You have to be certain the cost is worth the pay off :)
> Yet,
> >> >> > especially with user acceptance testing, I have to side with
> going
> >> >> with a
> >> >> > new framework, if simply for the reason that the client should
> be
> >> >> able to
> >> >> > read them.
> >> >> >
> >> >> > 2008/9/3 kentb <kentb@...>
> >> >>
> >> >> >
> >> >> > > Jan,
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > You can use JUnit for longer-running tests, but there are
> some
> >> >> assumptions
> >> >> > > JUnit embodies that will cause some problems. JUnit assumes
> tests
> >> >> are
> >> >> > > atomic--they run or don't run, they run in unit time.
> Integration
> >> >> tests
> >> >> > > often take a long time to run, so interim feedback is
> valuable.
> >> >> Integration
> >> >> > > tests can usefully have multiple failures, where that is
> less
> >> >> common with
> >> >> > > unit tests. OTOH, tests are tests--independent self-checking
> bits
> >> >> of code
> >> >> > > that run and get reported--and for that part of running
> >> >> integration tests
> >> >> > > JUnit works fine.
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > It seems to me to be a tradeoff between the simplicity of
> running
> >> >> all tests
> >> >> > > as JUnit tests and the challenges of getting the integration
> tests
> >> >> to run
> >> >> > > as
> >> >> > > JUnit tests. Different contexts will requires different
> solutions.
> >> >> If I had
> >> >> > > a few integration tests, I'd make them work with JUnit. If I
> had a
> >> >> large
> >> >> > > suite of integration tests that played a prominent role in
> >> >> development, I
> >> >> > > would use some other tool and integrate my unit testing
> results
> >> >> with the
> >> >> > > integration results.
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > Regards,
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > Kent Beck
> >> >> > > Three Rivers Institute
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > _____
> >> >> > >

> >> >> > > Subject: [junit] JUnit And Larger Scale Tests
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > Hi all!
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > I'm a bit of a newb to the whole TDD thing, but I understand
> that
> >> >> unit
> >> >> > > tests
> >> >> > > are supposed to be blazingly fast and not access the hard
> drive,
> >> >> network,
> >> >> > > database or anything external to the code itself. To this
> end, I
> >> >> understand
> >> >> > > that a framework such as jMock can be used.
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > So far, so good. But I find JUnit to be extremely useful for
> >> >> writing
> >> >> > > integration, system and user acceptance tests as well.
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > Here's my question: what is the official position of the
> JUnit
> >> >> community on
> >> >> > > using JUnit to do larger scale tests? Is there a better
> framework,
> >> >> or is it
> >> >> > > common practice to use JUnit for these tests as well?
> >> >> > >
> >> >> > > --
> >> >> > > Jan Kroeze
